== Early life and career ==

sentences: Early life and career
section: == Early life and career ==
== Early life and career ==

sentences: Peter Shapiro, who grew up in New York City, is the grandson of Ezra Shapiro, a former world chairman of the Keren Hayesod (the world’s largest fundraising organizations for Israel), and the great-grandnephew of Joel Elias Spingarn, one of the first Jewish leaders of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
section: == Early life and career ==

sentences: Shapiro’s father Daniel Shapiro was president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, the predecessor of the UJA-Federation of New York, from 1983 to 1986.
section: == Early life and career ==

sentences: Shapiro graduated from the Northwestern University School of Communications in 1995.
section: == Early life and career ==

sentences: During the summer between his sophomore and junior years, Shapiro shot the footage for his documentary debut
section: == Early life and career ==

sentences: And Miles To Go: On Tour with The Grateful Dead (1993).
section: == Early life and career ==

sentences: The project landed him an associate producer role on Tie-Died: Rock ‘n Roll’s Most Deadicated Fans, which debuted at Sundance in 1995 before its national theatrical run.
section: == Early life and career ==

sentences: All screenings of Tie-Died were preceded by Shapiro’s short film A Conversation with Ken Kesey, which originated during the making of And Miles To Go.
section: == Early life and career ==

sentences: Shapiro returned to Sundance in 1997 with American Road.
section: == Early life and career ==

sentences: This eight-minute short film, which he made with cinematographer Alex Cornfeld, presented images from the continental United States set to the Phish composition, "You Enjoy Myself."

== Wetlands Preserve ==

sentences: Wetlands Preserve ==
section: == Wetlands Preserve ==

sentences: In 1996, while touring college campuses with Tie-Died, Shapiro learned that Larry Bloch, the founder of New York City nightclub Wetlands Preserve, was seeking to sell the venue.
section: == Wetlands Preserve ==

sentences: Wetlands had opened seven years earlier as a self-styled “eco-saloon,” which not only focused on music but also supported a not-for-profit Center for Social and Environmental Justice.
section: == Wetlands Preserve ==

sentences: Bloch tapped Shapiro to shepherd in the club’s second era, despite the fact that the would-be owner had no prior club experience.
section: == Wetlands Preserve ==

sentences: When the club finally closed its doors in September 2001, the New York Times wrote, “the shuttering of Wetlands, which opened in 1989, is a major blow.”.
section: == Wetlands Preserve ==

sentences: The VW bus originally placed in the club as an information hub and a source of merchandise sales now resides in the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame.
section: == Wetlands Preserve ==

sentences: Shapiro and Bloch later appeared in the feature-length documentary Wetlands Preserved:
section: == Wetlands Preserve ==

sentences: The Story of An Activist Rock Club (2008)  directed by Dean Budnick, which utilizes archival footage, soundboard recordings and the efforts of a dozen digital animators to present the story of the venue and later aired on the Sundance Channel
section: == Wetlands Preserve ==

== The Capitol Theatre ==

sentences: The Capitol Theatre ==
section: == The Capitol Theatre ==

sentences: Shapiro's next project came to fruition on September 4, 2012 when Bob Dylan took the stage to mark the re-opening of the Capitol Theatre in Port Chester, NY.
section: == The Capitol Theatre ==

sentences: The facility was built in 1926 and designed by one of the era’s leading theater architects, Thomas W. Lamb.
section: == The Capitol Theatre ==

sentences: It first saw use as a concert space in 1970, hosting performances by The Grateful Dead, Pink Floyd, Janis Joplin and many others.
section: == The Capitol Theatre ==

sentences: Following a heyday of a few years, the facility experienced a brief resurgence in the 1990s with shows from Phish, Blues Traveler, Spin Doctors, Strangefolk and performances by The Rolling Stones and David Bowie as part of MTV’s
section: == The Capitol Theatre ==

sentences: Live From The 10 Spot series.
section: == The Capitol Theatre ==

sentences: In late 2011 Shapiro entered into an agreement with owner Marvin Ravikoff (who had been using the building as a special events facility for weddings and bar mitzvahs) to re-open it as a music venue.
section: == The Capitol Theatre ==

sentences: Over the ensuing months,  the New York Times reported, Shapiro “has spent more than $2 million renovating the 1,800-seat theater, which is 32 miles from Midtown Manhattan.
section: == The Capitol Theatre ==

sentences: He installed an arena-size lighting system, 10 high-definition projectors and an advanced sound system.
section: == The Capitol Theatre ==

sentences: The goal, he said, was to create ‘a psychedelic rock palace’ dedicated to live music, rather than theater.”
section: == The Capitol Theatre ==

sentences: Opening night was originally slated for September 7, 2012, Shapiro’s 40th birthday but the opportunity to put on a show with Dylan, who had previously used the theater as a tour rehearsal space, scuttled those plans by a few days.
section: == The Capitol Theatre ==

sentences: On December 31, 2012 the media reported that Shapiro had purchased the building for  $11.5 million from Ravikoff.
section: == The Capitol Theatre ==

sentences: Four months later after some additional renovation,  Shapiro christened the theatre’s new lobby bar and performance space as Garcia's in official tribute to the Grateful Dead guitarist.
section: == The Capitol Theatre ==

sentences: Jerry Garcia's daughter Trixie was on-hand and explained, "We chose to launch this idea at the Capitol because of its long and illustrious history with the Grateful Dead and the jam scene.
section: == The Capitol Theatre ==

sentences: We hope that it becomes a hub for the community to share stories and continue to build lifelong memories and friendships.
section: == The Capitol Theatre ==

sentences: Pete Shapiro and the Capitol Theatre staff were the appropriate partners to do this with because of our shared goals and his continued love and support of the Grateful Dead community.
section: == The Capitol Theatre ==

sentences: Just as important to note is the fact that Jerry's parents supported our family by owning and operating a bar in San Francisco in the 1940s and so it seemed right to reconnect with our family tradition."
section: == The Capitol Theatre ==

sentences: == FANS ==
section: == FANS ==

sentences: A few days prior to the 2016 Lockn' festival, Shapiro announced his latest venture, FANS.
section: == FANS ==

sentences: Ben Sisario reported in the New York Times, that Shapiro, "one of the most successful and least button-down independent music promoters in the country, is introducing his latest venture this week,an online platform called Fans.com that lets users build profiles based on concerts they have attended and communicate with like-minded people via news feeds."
section: == FANS ==

sentences: The article also suggests that FANS will eventually expand into sports and other areas that generate similar loyalty and passion.
section: == FANS ==

sentences: In a letter posted to Fans.com the following day, Shapiro wrote, "While that feeling of community is a vital part of the live music experience, it is glaringly absent online.
section: == FANS ==

sentences: The current digital fan experience is all over the place.
section: == FANS ==

sentences: Artist news, event databases, touring information, fan communities and music streaming exist in separate silos, with no true place for fans to congregate.
section: == FANS ==

sentences: Because of this fragmentation, meaningful memories and connections are often lost...FANS is an online community for you to embrace your passion for live music, celebrate your personal concert history, discover new experiences and connect with like-minded fans.
section: == FANS ==

sentences: Whether you’re a seasoned concertgoer or a casual listener, music provides a powerful path to happiness, community and memory.
section: == FANS ==

sentences: FANS is an open forum for self-expression and new discoveries for music-lovers of all stripes.
section: == FANS ==

sentences: "An
section: == FANS ==

sentences: April 2017 piece in WIRED, added that FANS "is Shapiro’s attempt to teleport some of [his] kinetic live-show power to the web.
section: == FANS ==

sentences: Launched last year, the site is an ever-growing concert database that includes everything from this month’s Chance the Rapper shows to, say, a 1960 Beatles gig in Hamburg, with many gigs documented via user-supplied photos and anecdotes.
section: == FANS ==

sentences: The goal is to build a single destination for concert lovers, who Shapiro says are often spread far across the web—either lingering on artist-specific sites like Little Monsters or Dead.net, or sharing everything via a decentralized stream of social media updates."
section: == FANS ==

== All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: In addition to his career as a concert promoter, Shapiro has continued to pursue film projects.
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: In 2001 along with his oldest brother Jon, he produced the IMAX concert film All Access: Front Row.
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: Backstage.
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: Live!.
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: Peter served as musical director for the film, which brought some of the Jammys sensibility to the big screen, as many of the performances are collaborative, including Al Green and the Dave Matthews Band (Take Me to the River'),' B. B. King, Trey Anastasio and The Roots  (Rock Me Baby), Carlos Santana and Rob Thomas (Smooth”), Sting and Cheb Mami (Desert Rose”) and George Clinton and Parliament-Funkadelic with Mary J. Blige (Flashlight, One Nation Under a Groove, Atomic Dog').”In December 2001 Peter and Jon recorded Chick Corea’s performances over three weeks at New York City’s Blue Note, in which Corea celebrated his 60th birthday with nine separate combos, spanning his career.
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: A live two-CD set earned Corea a Grammy, while the resulting film,  Rendezvous in New York (2004), narrated by Jeff Goldblum included appearance from such jazz figures as: Bobby McFerrin,  Joshua Redman, Terence Blanchard, Michael Brecker, Steve Gadd and Christian McBride.
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: They continued to work together over the years to follow, placing an increased emphasis on 3D technology, becoming partners in 3ality Digital.
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: Their most high-profile collaboration to date was the 2007 concert film U2 3D. Shot in South America during the group’s 2006 Vertigo Tour, U2 3D with up to 18 3D cameras utilized simultaneously, capturing digital footage.
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: Peter initially pitched the idea to the group’s director for visual content, Catherine Owens who would go on to direct along with Mark Pellington (Arlington Road, The Mothman Chronicles).
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: The film premiered at the 2008 Sundance Film Festival (following a preview screening at the 2007 Cannes Film Festival).
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: It received international release in 2008 through National Geographic Entertainment.
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: Variety called it “Breathtaking when performance, technology and cinematography click at the same moment” and the New York Times dubbed it “The first Imax movie that deserves to be called a work of art.”
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: It is one of the top 10 grossing concert films of all-time.
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: Following U2 3D, the Shapiros continued to explore the use of 3D for capturing live entertainment.
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: On December 4, 2008 they broadcast the first-ever live 3D football game to theaters in Los Angeles, New York and Boston, pitting the Oakland Raiders against the San Diego Chargers.
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: A few weeks later they brought the BCS Championship game between Florida and Oklahoma to 80 theatres across the country.
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: A year later, on March 30, 2010 the Black Eyed Peas became the first music group to simulcast a live concert in 3D, as their sold-out performance at the Staples Center in Los Angeles reached audiences across the nation via Regal Cinema theatres.
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: Shapiro also served as a producer for Sheryl Crow: C’mon America (2003), And You Don’t Stop: 30 Years of Hip-Hop (2004),
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: Dion: Live (2004) and  Toots and The Maytals – True Love (2004).
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: During the summer of 2004 he also brought some performances from the SummerStage series in Central Park to the air for the first time in the facility’s 19-year history.
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: The hour-long Live From Central Park SummerStage aired on New York’s
section: == All Access, U2 3D and Music on Film ==

sentences: WABC-TV on six successive Saturday nights at 11:35, with performances by Ben Folds, Guster, Rufus Wainwright,  Devo, the Yeah Yeah Yeahs and Stellastarr.

sentences: In 2009 he co-produced the videos that appeared at We Are One: The Obama Inaugural Celebration at the Lincoln Memorial and also aired on HBO.

== Relix ==

sentences: Relix ==
section: == Relix ==

sentences: In April 2009 Shapiro became the principal owner of Relix magazine.
section: == Relix ==

sentences: He purchased the magazine (along with Relix.com and Jambands.com) from Steve Bernstein who had announced its closing two months earlier due to financial constraints.
section: == Relix ==

sentences: Shapiro became publisher, heading a staff that also included current editors Dean Budnick and Mike Greenhaus, Associate Publisher Rachel Seiden and former editor Josh Baron.
section: == Relix ==

sentences: In June 2009 Shapiro wrote a publisher’s note entitled, Welcome to Relix 3.0, where he stated in part, “It is with great respect and appreciation that I am assuming the role of Publisher of Relix magazine.
section: == Relix ==

sentences: I follow in the footsteps of a distinguished group of people that each made an enormous effort in order to make this magazine what it is today…I am proud to say that Relix is a strong relevant and influential as ever.
section: == Relix ==

sentences: In many ways the magazine and its sister websites, Relix.com and Jambands.com, reflect the sustained strength of a community of millions of people, who live their lives with music as a core spiritual and experiential driver…We live in difficult times and as we have all heard, many are predicting the demise of magazines.
section: == Relix ==

sentences: Well, in many ways, Relix has always gone in a direction away from the mainstream and popular belief, forging its own path.
section: == Relix ==

sentences: Now is no different.
section: == Relix ==

sentences: Despite the dire warning and predictions we have faith in the power of our community: the fans, musicians, industry and most importantly…Relix!
section: == Relix ==

sentences: We hope you join us for the ride.”
section: == Relix ==

sentences: Founded in 1974, Relix is currently the second longest running magazine devoted to rock music published in the United States.
section: == Relix ==

sentences: HeadCount and other Nonprofit Work

== HeadCount and other Nonprofit Work ==

sentences: Shapiro has maintained a steady slate of volunteer efforts.
section: == HeadCount and other Nonprofit Work ==

sentences: For a number of years he served on the Board of Directors of the City Parks Foundation Arts Committee, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit that creates programs throughout the five boroughs of New York City.
section: == HeadCount and other Nonprofit Work ==

sentences: He was a founding board member of HeadCount, advising the “a non-partisan organization that uses the power of music to register voters and promote participation in democracy” and in July 2019, he became Chairman of the Board.
section: == HeadCount and other Nonprofit Work ==
== Jam The Vote, Women's March, March for Science ==

sentences: Jam The Vote, Women's March, March for Science ==
section: == Jam The Vote, Women's March, March for Science ==

sentences: On the evening of Sunday November 6, 2016 just 36 hours prior to the general election, Shapiro produced a special, innovative Jam The Vote event at the Capitol Theatre, working with Preservation Hall Jazz Band Musical Director Ben Jaffe, and HeadCount Executive Director Andy Bernstein.
section: == Jam The Vote, Women's March, March for Science ==

sentences: Preservation Hall Jazz Band and Blind Boys Of Alabama served as house band with guests that included Questlove, Win Butler, Craig Finn, Eugene Hutz, Nicole Atkins and Robert Randolph.
section: == Jam The Vote, Women's March, March for Science ==

sentences: The show was available for free via an innovative live stream in which viewers were asked to pledge to vote in order to gain access to the multi-camera broadcast.
section: == Jam The Vote, Women's March, March for Science ==

sentences: Once logged in they were also able to learn additional information about their polling place, including ID requirements to vote.
section: == Jam The Vote, Women's March, March for Science ==

sentences: On January 21, 2017 Shapiro oversaw the filming and live streaming of the 2017 Women's March on Washington.
section: == Jam The Vote, Women's March, March for Science ==

sentences: The stream was available on Facebook, YouTube and through multiple major media outlets.
section: == Jam The Vote, Women's March, March for Science ==

sentences: Three months later, on April 22, 2017, he served as producer for the March for Science event in Washington, DC.
section: == Jam The Vote, Women's March, March for Science ==
